title: Treu departure 'nothing to do with fallout'
text:
Sport Treu departure 'nothing to do with fallout'

Western Province has put its sudden parting of ways with former Blitzboks coach Paul Treu down to rugby’s pitiful economics and not any bad blood resulting from the fallout following last year’s discrimination investigation he had instituted into its labour practices.

Treu’s official complaint led to 29 people being interviewed before an independent legal firm found no adverse findings against Western Province in November. He had a falling out with then fellow Super Rugby coaches Robbie Fleck and Paul Feeney, but then, surprisingly, looked to have been rewarded – or placated – with the new role of performance and innovation manager in March.

Now it has emerged that when the former Blitzbok and SWD Eagles winger’s contract expires next month, he will be one of several people, ironically including Fleck, Feeney and forwards coach Russell Winter, whose contracts were not renewed by the provincial union – only six months into his new role.

Most observers would look at that outcome and put two and two together, but Western Province chief executive Paul Zacks this week insisted that this wasn’t a case of delayed payback, but rather that finances dictated that they make the call.

“It’s the same as Winter, Fleck and Feeney, you know ... contracts come to an end and there’s a new [Stormers] management team in place – it’s nothing more than that,” explained Zacks.

At the time, Treu’s new role was hailed by Province as having been created to “supplement” their revamped coaching structures and being “in line with international best practice”.

But Zacks said that, despite the title having the word ‘innovative’ in it, it was hardly a new portfolio and it wasn’t a deal that extended beyond the length of Treu’s contract.

“It wasn’t really a new position as such,” he said.

I don’t think it’s a secret that all the franchises are struggling financially

“It was an attempt to see what innovation we could bring to the business. Obviously, Paul did some work for us there around performance management systems, but at the end of the day, it’s a business decision in terms of what we can financially afford.

“I don’t think it’s a secret that all the franchises are struggling financially and, as a result, we had to rationalise the rugby department. The board and executive committee made that decision and, unfortunately, the outcome is the one we’ve arrived at,” he said.

“And this doesn’t just apply to Feeney. Fleck’s been in our system for 20 years – 10 as a player and 10 as a coach – that’s a lot of intellectual property, but, financially, we just couldn’t afford it. It’s not a personal decision at all, it’s purely business and purely financial, and about the new head coach being allowed to appoint his own management team.”

A Province insider made their financial situation sound dire, saying that they had gone from having 150-odd contracted players to about 70, including Under-21 players. He also said they would be relying on freelance coaches to coach junior teams such as the Under-21s and the SuperSport Rugby Challenge.

That said, another insider suggested that Treu could still stay on in a role that has yet to be defined. According to the source, the Western Province politics are such that Treu is not popular with the board but has support in the executive committee, which includes president Zelt Marais.

Consequently, it sounds as though a fair bit of water needs to go under the bridge before Treu finally parts ways with Province.

Treu, Fleck, Feeney and Winter not having their contracts renewed comes in the wake of the Lions doing the same with Joey Mongalo and Bart Schoeman in what seems to be a countrywide bid to cut expenses down to the bone.

Quite what that will mean for the franchises’ performances especially considering that Treu’s role was supposed to provide a scientific and research-based sounding board to the coaches at the coalface – is a mystery.

Treu would not comment when contacted because he is still working for Western Province.
description: Chief executive Zacks insists that, just like other franchises, they are cutting costs.
